keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by President Trump in 2021 after participating in the Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan allegedly sent text messages threatening to kill Jeffries, stating 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.'
The arrest comes amid a broader national concern about recidivism among individuals pardoned following the Jan. 6 Capitol riot, with law enforcement reporting a surge in threat assessments.

Moynihan had previously been sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and received a full pardon as part of a blanket pardon of over 1,500 Capitol riot defendants.
Hakeem Jeffries responded to the arrest by criticizing the pardon, stating that many pardoned individuals have committed additional violent crimes, putting public safety at risk.

The incident underscores growing public and political scrutiny of the Trump administration's blanket pardon of Capitol riot participants and its potential impact on national security and law enforcement capacity.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6, 2021 Capitol riot who was pardoned by President Trump, has been arrested for allegedly sending threatening texts to U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, stating he would 'kill him for the future' and 'must be eliminated.' The arrest, made by New York State Police after FBI intelligence, follows Moynihan’s prior 2023 sentencing and pardon. The incident occurs amid growing public and law enforcement concern about recidivism among pardoned rioters, with the Capitol Police reporting a surge in threat assessments. Critics, including Jeffries, argue that such blanket pardons allow dangerous individuals to reoffend, undermining public safety and law enforcement capacity.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
